docs.lead_paragraph: Companies and insurers that provide health coverage for employee groups face a deadline of midnight Monday to inform the state whether they will contribute to state funds to subsidize health care for the poor and for physician training. Employers that miss the deadline will face big increases in hospital charges for their employees, under a law enacted this summer that will end the state's system of setting hospital rates.

headline.main: Companies Face Deadline On New Health-Care Funds

docs.abstract: Companies and insurers that provide health coverage for employee groups face deadline for informing New York State whether they will contribute to state fund to subsidize health care for the poor and for physician training; employers not joining pool face extra charges for hospital care (S)
docs.snippet: Companies and insurers that provide health coverage for employee groups face a deadline of midnight Monday to inform the state whether they will contribute to state funds to subsidize health care for the poor and for physician training.    Employers...

docs.lead_paragraph: Every evening as I take the freeway home after a day of seeing patients and teaching medical students at El Paso's sole county hospital, I whiz by ''Pill Hill,'' the area around Sierra Medical Center, where my colleagues in private practice work. The locations of our hospitals epitomize our differences. My hospital, R. E. Thomason General, is down on the plain, just off the freeway, next to a cemetery, in the heart of a barrio of transmission shops, very-used-car lots, pawnshops and cheap motels. From the eighth floor of the hospital, a long tee shot would sail over the Rio Grande and into Juarez, Mexico.

headline.main: My Hospital, Dying a Slow Death

docs.abstract: Abraham Verghese Op-Ed article holds that the hospital where he works, R E Thomason General, a county hospital in El Paso, Tex, cannot possibly survive if the area's for-profit hospitals continue to draw away its Medicaid base, which helps Thomason meet its mandate of caring for the uninsured; notes that Medicaid patients are sought out by for-profit hospitals now that managed care has pushed down the cost of serving most patients to the level of Medicaid reimbursement; asks what will happen to the uninsured if Thomason is closed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Every evening as I take the freeway home after a day of seeing patients and teaching medical students at El Paso's sole county hospital, I whiz by ''Pill Hill,'' the area around Sierra Medical Center, where my colleagues in private practice work.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: A majority of the board of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation has sided with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani in approving a long-term lease of Coney Island Hospital to a commercial company. The Giuliani administration is confident that the deal will save millions for the city, while preserving care for the poor. But before state officials give their required approval, there are important unanswered questions that need to be addressed. Mr. Giuliani has long pushed to privatize or lease city hospitals in an effort to cut health costs and overhaul care for the poor. Coney Island was one of the first hospitals to be put on the auction block. Nestled in a neighborhood of elderly and poor people, it has 460 beds and a number of outpatient services. But surveys indicate that about two-thirds of nearby residents seek health care elsewhere.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges state officials to examine fine print of Giuliani administration's plan to lease Coney Island Hospital to Primary Health Systems, commercial company, and determine whether deal can live up to its promise (M)
